page.title: 06ST.PETER'S - HURSTBOURNE
page.content: {St.Peter's Church}at{Hurstbourne {Tarrant}was started in 1180. The oldest remaining part of it is the arch in the porch, on either side of which is an animal's head. As you go into the church, the head on the right is of a lion and on the left is an eagle's head. They are not realistic, probably because the artist had never seen a lion or an eagle. The pillars are very big and solid, and there is some mediaeval graffiti scratched on some of those in the south aisle. The outline of a bird, and what looks like a gallows can be seen. The font is also very old and the tiles under it have been dated to the 12th century. The Sanctuary tiles were later made to match them. Some original wall paintings can still be seen in the north aisle.
